pullRequest.body:
First definition of Quantales - a non-commutative generalization of Locales/Frames. There are still some points of discussion, which would require changes elsewhere in Mathlib, but this definition should be workeable as a starting point (I think).
It's my first PR, but I've tried to stay close to what I've seen in CompleteLattices.

---

@j-loreaux Do I understand correctly that removing the `awaiting author` label will draw your attention to these files again?
I've made quite a few changes, but the file now also starts to grow a bit...

Yes, generally, although it is also possible to request review. 

I see that you now also consider semigroups, which has led to a proliferation of classes. I think there is yet another possibility to consider here: make the algebraic structure an argument to the class rather than extending it.

So you would write


```lean
class Quantale (\a : Type*) [Semigroup \a] extends CompleteLattice \a where ...`
```

The downside is that you have to write *two* things to get a quantale, but the upside is that you can easily change the underlying algebraic structure without defining all new classes.

So, to get a bare bones quantale, you just write:  but to get a commutative unital one, you simply change this to: `[CommMonoid \a] [Quantale \a]`.

After that, you could potentially make `IsIdem` or `IsIntegral` mixin classes. It depends on how often they come up, and whether they come up in conjunction with each other. This is hard for me to say with my limited knowledge of quantales.

> So you would write
> 
> ```lean
> class Quantale (\a : Type*) [Semigroup \a] extends CompleteLattice \a where ...`
> ```
> 
> The downside is that you have to write _two_ things to get a quantale, but the upside is that you can easily change the underlying algebraic structure without defining all new classes.
> 

That does not seem the best way to go to me. I think the definition I have now for quantales fits best.
As I explain in the preceding comments, the term is not completely consistent within literature, with some authors
using it for a semigroup and others using it for a monoid, so we have to decide on which stance Mathlib will take on it.
But in many papers I actually see it acknowledged that the original is without assuming the unit element, to subsequently
say: but in this paper we use the term to mean a unital quantale. Therefore, from a Mathlib point of view, I guess it is okay
to drag along the OneQuantale whenever a paper you are formalizing says Quantale.

The construct you are proposing would make sense if the general way of looking at it is that "you turn a semigroup into a quantale", but (just like with a ring consisting of two semigroups) that is not the way quantales are being used imo.

Thanks for thinking along though! It really helps to have someone giving feedback :-)

I think you are getting hung up on interpretations. You don't have to think of it as "turning a monoid into a quantale". Instead, you can think of it as: "a semigroup is the minimal algebraic structure necessary for a quantale".

Just for comparison, `Module R M` takes two type class arguments: `AddCommMonoid M` and `Semiring R`. So, to get a vector space over a field, you have to write `[AddCommGroup V] [Field K] [Module K V]`.

I would encourage you to throw out preconceptions about how things "should" look based on how you think of it before formalization. Sometimes the requirements of formalization make things different.

Thanks... easier said than done though ;-)
It turns out now that the decision to go for additive versions of Quantales causes a clash with Semirings.
The add_idem has been defined there already, and again I have to let go of some preconceptions...

Come to think of it... when you say "a semigroup is the minimal algebraic structure necessary for a quantale", that may touch upon the problem that I have with understanding the best way to build a library. There is not a single unique "minimal structure" for many things, and the choice for one over another will lead to problems down the road at some point. 

For example, today I was stuck on understanding idempotent semirings. The textual description says it is a semiring with an idempotent operator - fair enough, just what you would expect. But then the formalization says it is a semiring and a sup-semilattice in which addition coincides with supremum. That is actually a much more assuming (and certainly not minimal) description of it (and it kind-off contradicts the name). In fact, there may be multiple ways to turn a semiring into a sup-semilattice. Indeed, when it is an idempotent semiring, choosing the order to match $$x \leq y$$ iff $x + y = y$$ is a natural option, but the reverse is always an option as well. 

I don't think the formalization of it all forces one direction or another. But I do understand that in some branches of mathematics people have come to think of the structure in one way (as an algebraic property of the +), and in other branches they think of the same structure in another way (as an order-theoretic property of the +). In this case, the latter group of people got to developing that part of the library first, so the first group of people will have to adapt a bit. Formalization seems to have trouble allowing both sides to be happy on the same footing, unless you are prepared to drag around a lot of references, making both sides unhappy really.

> In fact, there may be multiple ways to turn a semiring into a sup-semilattice. Indeed, when it is an idempotent semiring, choosing the order to match $$x \leq y$$ iff $x + y = y$$ is a natural option, but the reverse is always an option as well.

> I don't think the formalization of it all forces one direction or another. But I do understand that in some branches of mathematics people have come to think of the structure in one way (as an algebraic property of the +), and in other branches they think of the same structure in another way (as an order-theoretic property of the +). In this case, the latter group of people got to developing that part of the library first, so the first group of people will have to adapt a bit.

I don't agree with this assessment at all. Sure, there are many ways to put a sup-semilattice on a semiring, it's just that the structures won't be related (and you can do that in Lean). But in an idempotent semiring, there's a canonical way to do it so that they *are*. And there's no need to think of one structure generating the other. They both just exist, and the axioms force them to play nice. So there's not necessarily anything here about one group getting more say about how things develop (although that sort of thing surely does happen sometimes).

I've tried out your suggestion of making the definition dependent on the Semigroup.
I like the way it makes the definition more independent.
The problem I encountered with add_idem clashing in Kleene now disappears for the time being, because there is no need to have separate definitions for properties that are actually only targetting the Semigroup. Those should go elsewhere. So only the IsIntegral property stays and is not a mix-in class.

Now I bump into being a novice on Git. I need to figure out how to undo my changes to Kleene and IsIdem to get a clean PR... Any suggestions? (Concretely, I need to restore an old version of the Kleene file and remove the IsIdem file for the PR, preferably in such a way that I can easily put them back afterwards when I continue to actually proof theorems about idempotent quantales - because that is when I need them.)

> > I don't think the formalization of it all forces one direction or another. But I do understand that in some branches of mathematics people have come to think of the structure in one way (as an algebraic property of the +), and in other branches they think of the same structure in another way (as an order-theoretic property of the +). In this case, the latter group of people got to developing that part of the library first, so the first group of people will have to adapt a bit.
> 
> I don't agree with this assessment at all. Sure, there are many ways to put a sup-semilattice on a semiring, it's just that the structures won't be related (and you can do that in Lean). But in an idempotent semiring, there's a canonical way to do it so that they _are_. And there's no need to think of one structure generating the other. They both just exist, and the axioms force them to play nice. So there's not necessarily anything here about one group getting more say about how things develop (although that sort of thing surely does happen sometimes).

I agree. I may not be expressing myself clearly where my concern really is. 

What I ran into during an earlier small project, is that I thought I had defined an arbitrary order structure to work on in combination with an algebraic structure. I had no intention of using the canonical order, which apparently also exists. But only when I got into the proofs I found out Lean interpreted me defining an order structure as well as an algebraic structure as "oh he means the canonical one". So all of a sudden I was provided with axioms that I didn't actually want to have and that invalidated my theorem. Luckily, actually, because the same could happen the other way around. If you don't notice that under the hood there is an order structure defined, you might accidentally use that one while the definitions really seem to suggest something else. Such confusions make me quite uncertain when using Lean, so I try to keep control over what is defined and what is not.

Do you have similar experiences?
I took this discussion to Zulip privately so we don't clutter the PR.

Welcome to Mathlib! I've left some comments to get you started. Please let me / us know if you have questions. Also, please see the [commit conventions](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/commit.html) about the PR title and description.
Are you saying that `x * sInf s =  y  s, x * y` *isn't* always true? Or are you saying that it is, but there are two types of *morphisms* between quantales that are usually considered?

The definition of quantales only requires sSup to distribute over *, not inf.
Whether what you wrote follows from that definition, I would have to think about a little.
But it would be a theorem, not a definition.

These should be `IsIntegral`, `IsComm` and `IsIdem`. And presumably you would want them to be `class`es, right? Although, I'm not yet convinced that you want them to be mix-in classes.

For example, you want to conclude that a commutative quantale is a commutative monoid, no? What I'm arguing for here would be `CommQuantale ( : Type*) extends CommMonoid , CompleteLattice  where ...`

I'll change the spelling, thanks.
Not sure if they need to be classes... what would be the arguments for and against?
And what is a mix-in class?

Well, if `IsComm` were not a class, then every time you wanted to use the fact about `CommMonoid`s for your commutative quantale, you would need to first activate `Quantale` + `IsComm`  `CommMonoid` instance manually. This would be a pain, and it's probably not what you want. For the others, I'm less sure whether they should be classes, as I don't really know what the use cases are.

Now, as for a mix-in, this is what these classes would be if you just changed them to `class` instead of `def` right now (and, if you did that, you should explicitly mark their type as `Prop`). A mix-in is a class which takes another class as an argument, but only adds `Prop`-valued fields. An example of this in the library would be `IsDomain`. In contrast, we don't use this pattern everywhere. For example, we don't write `Ring R` with `IsComm R` to specify a commutative ring. Instead, we write `CommRing R`, and the structure `CommRing` instead `extends` the structure `Ring`. This means that a `CommRing` carries with it a ring structure, instead of needing one supplied to it.

Reasons for preferring one to the other are related to convenience, performance or parallelism, or yet other reasons. In this case, I would almost certainly argue that `IsComm` should *not* be a mix-in, if for no other reason than we want the parallelism with the rest of the library. You can read more about the algebraic hierarchy in Mathlib in the book "Mathematics in Lean".

My guess is that all properties are "at the same level as Comm" in this case, so I've updated the file to reflect this. Of course, we will only know once we start to actually prove things. I now have based the file mostly on the wikipedia entry on Quantales, which means there is one theorem that "obviously" needs to be proven, namely that every IdemIntegralQuantale is a Order.Frame. Will work on that shortly - but I was hoping the definitions can be approved before that?

style
```suggestion
on complete lattices, but for a non-commutative logic.
I.e. `x  y = sSup { z | z * x  y }`.
```
I don't think this should be a global notation. I think it should be `scoped` to the `Quantale` namespace.
Agree. What is the code for that? I thought defining it within the namespace would be sufficient.
I think it's just `scoped infixr....`, but I might be misremembering.
That seems to do it, indeed. Thnx.

style, we generally leave gaps between declarations, and I would probably just use the word `left` instead of abbreviating it in the name. This name is not too long that it needs abbreviations.
```suggestion
def left_residuation (x y : ) := sSup { z | z * x  y }

/-- Notation for left-residuation in quantales.
```

I think you *really* don't want to go the `CompleteSemilatticeSup` route. Indeed, you will lose out on *many* lemmas about `CompleteLattice`s that way, which will just cause pain. Even if in the theory of quantales one never needs the `inf`, it's still useful to have the full structure around. If a use wants to only provide the `CompleteSemilatticeSup` structure and then have it upgraded to a `CompleteLattice` for free, we have a constructor that does that (which will make the defeqs for `inf` and `sInf` terrible, but as you indicate, it's possible that won't matter).

As for the morphisms, there's no problem: when you get around to defining them, just define them to only preserve the join.

I see. So in fact you only have the CompleteSemilatticeSup in order to be able to prove that it is a CompleteLattice, and then build everything on that.

I first thought it was conceptually nicer to `only have a CompleteSemilatticeSup' since my own intuition for using Quantales is that the `inf' is not meaningful. But considering it meaningful or not is, I now realize, a bias on my part - based on how I happen to think of them at this point in time. If I let go of that, and in a library you must be able to support all kinds of uses, then it makes sense to just add everything you can reasonably define, and you end up with complete lattices. Thanks... I learned something today :-)

Unless you use `to_additive`, you're only defining multiplicative quantales below. Maybe you should do both? (Note: you'll need to provide the `class` manually first, and then mark the multiplicative one with `to_additive`. See for example, how `Monoid` and `AddMonoid` are declared.)

Thanks, that is indeed what I want ultimately. But since this is my first PR, I figured I should keep it simple and get used to the process first.

Also, when I was looking at AddMonoid, it was not completely clear to me yet how to_additive works. But that's a next step to figure out for me.

`to_additive` should mostly "Just Work", except that for `class`es and `structure`s you have to declare them manually separately first (additive one first so that when you add the attribute to the multiplicative one it sees the existing additive declaration). Mostly, it works by finding the right name of the additive lemma and then inserting that everywhere. There is a dictionary for this, which isn't too hard to guess (`one`  `zero`, `mul`  `add`, `pow`  `smul`, etc.). There are edge cases where you need to do something manually, but if you have any trouble, just ask on Zulip.
Ah, apparently I needed to update ToAdditive.Frontend as well, adding `Quantale` as a recognized thing to which to_additive applies. After that, things went smoothly indeed.

Yes, generally, although it is also possible to request review. 

I see that you now also consider semigroups, which has led to a proliferation of classes. I think there is yet another possibility to consider here: make the algebraic structure an argument to the class rather than extending it.

So you would write


```lean
class Quantale (\a : Type*) [Semigroup \a] extends CompleteLattice \a where ...`
```

The downside is that you have to write *two* things to get a quantale, but the upside is that you can easily change the underlying algebraic structure without defining all new classes.

So, to get a bare bones quantale, you just write:  but to get a commutative unital one, you simply change this to: `[CommMonoid \a] [Quantale \a]`.

After that, you could potentially make `IsIdem` or `IsIntegral` mixin classes. It depends on how often they come up, and whether they come up in conjunction with each other. This is hard for me to say with my limited knowledge of quantales.

> So you would write

> 
> The downside is that you have to write _two_ things to get a quantale, but the upside is that you can easily change the underlying algebraic structure without defining all new classes.

That does not seem the best way to go to me. I think the definition I have now for quantales fits best.
As I explain in the preceding comments, the term is not completely consistent within literature, with some authors
using it for a semigroup and others using it for a monoid, so we have to decide on which stance Mathlib will take on it.
But in many papers I actually see it acknowledged that the original is without assuming the unit element, to subsequently
say: but in this paper we use the term to mean a unital quantale. Therefore, from a Mathlib point of view, I guess it is okay
to drag along the OneQuantale whenever a paper you are formalizing says Quantale.

The construct you are proposing would make sense if the general way of looking at it is that "you turn a semigroup into a quantale", but (just like with a ring consisting of two semigroups) that is not the way quantales are being used imo.

Thanks for thinking along though! It really helps to have someone giving feedback :-)

I think you are getting hung up on interpretations. You don't have to think of it as "turning a monoid into a quantale". Instead, you can think of it as: "a semigroup is the minimal algebraic structure necessary for a quantale".

Just for comparison, `Module R M` takes two type class arguments: `AddCommMonoid M` and `Semiring R`. So, to get a vector space over a field, you have to write `[AddCommGroup V] [Field K] [Module K V]`.

I would encourage you to throw out preconceptions about how things "should" look based on how you think of it before formalization. Sometimes the requirements of formalization make things different.

Thanks... easier said than done though ;-)
It turns out now that the decision to go for additive versions of Quantales causes a clash with Semirings.
The add_idem has been defined there already, and again I have to let go of some preconceptions...

Come to think of it... when you say "a semigroup is the minimal algebraic structure necessary for a quantale", that may touch upon the problem that I have with understanding the best way to build a library. There is not a single unique "minimal structure" for many things, and the choice for one over another will lead to problems down the road at some point. 

For example, today I was stuck on understanding idempotent semirings. The textual description says it is a semiring with an idempotent operator - fair enough, just what you would expect. But then the formalization says it is a semiring and a sup-semilattice in which addition coincides with supremum. That is actually a much more assuming (and certainly not minimal) description of it (and it kind-off contradicts the name). In fact, there may be multiple ways to turn a semiring into a sup-semilattice. Indeed, when it is an idempotent semiring, choosing the order to match $$x \leq y$$ iff $x + y = y$$ is a natural option, but the reverse is always an option as well. 

I don't think the formalization of it all forces one direction or another. But I do understand that in some branches of mathematics people have come to think of the structure in one way (as an algebraic property of the +), and in other branches they think of the same structure in another way (as an order-theoretic property of the +). In this case, the latter group of people got to developing that part of the library first, so the first group of people will have to adapt a bit. Formalization seems to have trouble allowing both sides to be happy on the same footing, unless you are prepared to drag around a lot of references, making both sides unhappy really.

> In fact, there may be multiple ways to turn a semiring into a sup-semilattice. Indeed, when it is an idempotent semiring, choosing the order to match $$x \leq y$$ iff $x + y = y$$ is a natural option, but the reverse is always an option as well.

> I don't think the formalization of it all forces one direction or another. But I do understand that in some branches of mathematics people have come to think of the structure in one way (as an algebraic property of the +), and in other branches they think of the same structure in another way (as an order-theoretic property of the +). In this case, the latter group of people got to developing that part of the library first, so the first group of people will have to adapt a bit.

I don't agree with this assessment at all. Sure, there are many ways to put a sup-semilattice on a semiring, it's just that the structures won't be related (and you can do that in Lean). But in an idempotent semiring, there's a canonical way to do it so that they *are*. And there's no need to think of one structure generating the other. They both just exist, and the axioms force them to play nice. So there's not necessarily anything here about one group getting more say about how things develop (although that sort of thing surely does happen sometimes).

I agree. I may not be expressing myself clearly where my concern really is. 

What I ran into during an earlier small project, is that I thought I had defined an arbitrary order structure to work on in combination with an algebraic structure. I had no intention of using the canonical order, which apparently also exists. But only when I got into the proofs I found out Lean interpreted me defining an order structure as well as an algebraic structure as "oh he means the canonical one". So all of a sudden I was provided with axioms that I didn't actually want to have and that invalidated my theorem. Luckily, actually, because the same could happen the other way around. If you don't notice that under the hood there is an order structure defined, you might accidentally use that one while the definitions really seem to suggest something else. Such confusions make me quite uncertain when using Lean, so I try to keep control over what is defined and what is not.

Do you have similar experiences?
